course.subject: LANG
course.name: Chinese for Non-Chinese Language Background Students V
course.description: This course builds on the groundwork laid in LANG 1120, LANG 1121 and LANG 1122 and LANG 1123, and takes students to an intermediate-high level of understanding of spoken Chinese and a stronger communicative competence in using Chinese in social and professional situations. Restricted to students with non-Chinese language backgrounds only. Students without the prerequisite but with approximate 200 hours of prior Chinese learning experience may seek instructor’s approval for enrollment in the course.
course.exclusions: HKDSE/HKALE/HKCEE/JEE Chinese, LANG 1113, LANG 1114 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1115 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1116 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1117, LANG 1118

reviews.author: whalewhalewhale
reviews.comment_content:
There's around 9 chapters in total that you will be learning. For those who took GCSE Chinese, you would find the content of the lesson to be quite similar, as it includes topics, such as dream job, summer/ winter holiday, etc.
This course is in simplified Chinese, and each chapter has a list of new vocabulary to learn (more than 50 words in each list).
The course would also test you on your grammar, such as rearranging a scrambled sentence, and also works on your listening through recordings from the textbook. You would also have to read through the passages in the textbook, though they have a paragraph showing the pin yin, which is quite convenient.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very friendly professor; encourages you to participate in class, and tries to make the lesson enjoyable; Very willing to help the students improve their Chinese
reviews.comment_grading:
For quizzes, there will be around 3 during the semester, and they contain content from 3-4 chapters. The professor also gives us the guidelines on the oral quiz, so you can prepare beforehand. You can also make a PowerPoint during the oral presentation.
The listening quiz format is a bit strange, since the MCs only show A, B, C and D, and does not show any text. You have to listen very carefully to the recording to know what does A, B, C and D have as their answers.
5% will also be counted for class attendance and participation.
I would say the grading is quite competitive. Most of the students in this class are experienced in Mandarin and have high marks in their assignments, but even so, some of us got B-B+ range.
reviews.comment_workload: Not very heavy. There is usually only one assignment per chapter, and it is mainly essays. The professor usually discusses how to answer/ tackle the essay, so it makes the assignment not too difficult.

reviews.author: gonpachirou
reviews.title: Excellent teacher. Great content design. Improved my Chinese a lot.
reviews.comment_content:
There are EIGHT chapters, SEVEN of which were covered in the Spring 21-22 semester.
第一单元 我行我见
第一课 假期回顾
第二课 中国印象
第三课 我爱汉语
第二单元 我思我想
第四课 年轻得一代
第五课 大学生的生活
第六课 我的重大决定
第三单元 走向职场
第七课 机遇的挑战
第八课 我的理想
第九课 我已经准备好了

First lecture is Self-introduction
自己介绍
Nickname / Chinese name
Faculty
Hobbies
Holiday
Do you like Hong Kong
Motivation for studying Chinese

I'll just paste some of my NOTES here to give you an idea of the difficulty of a typical class discussion.

[FEBRUARY 11 2022]
犯错误 → make mistakes (v.)
集中 → focus (v.)
事情 → matter (n.）
喝酒 → drink alcohol (v.)
喝醉 → get drunk (v.)
停止 → stop (v.)
注意 → pay attention
左右 → about (usage same as ぐらい)
不仅…还/也… → not only, but also
宽阔><狭窄 → broad><narrow
In written language, the two-character word is used
In spoken language, the highlighted words are used.
比比皆是 → can be ound everywhere
高楼大厦比比皆是 → high-rise buildings can be found everywhere
以前读过大学的人很少，但现在大学生比比皆是 → Before, there were very little university graduates, but now university students are to be found everywhere.
寒假，暑假，春假 → winter/summer/spring holiday
先，然后，最后 → firstly, next, lastly
四通八达 → 任何的地方都可以去到
感受 & 感觉 (difference?) → 感受 inside / heart feeling, 感觉 outside / physical feeling
提前
• 如果要练习口语，要提前10分钟进入教室
赶
• 赶飞机，赶火车，赶巴士
本来
• 他今天没有来上课，原来生病了。
当
• 当老师，当经理(manager)
豁然开朗→ same meaning as 突然明白

（1）As soon as you stop paying attention when writing, it’s easy to make mistakes.
写作文的时候已停止注意就很容易犯错。
（2）Tom can’t drink. Once he drinks, he gets drunk easily.
Tom不能喝酒。一喝酒就会很快地喝醉。
（3）Wang Li is very smart. No matter what it is, once she gets into it, she can learn it very fast.
王丽特别聪明。不管是什么事情，他能很快地了解。

Reading Comprehension
麦克为什么说自己没有那么幸运？（虽然……但是）
→ 虽然他去中国大陆了，但是他没有交到中国朋友。
麦克去了哪些地方？（首先……然后……最后）
→ 他先去了西安古城，然后去了北京，从北京又到了上海，最后去了桂林。
麦克对中国的印象是什么？
→ 他觉得中国是一个很大的国家，经济发展很快。

Practice using 本来（1），原来（2）

21112
reviews.comment_teaching: Excellent teaching making use of class discussion, in-class practice, recall, both written and oral assessments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy is as follows
- Written assessment 1 (25%)
      - Listening 10%, Reading 5%, Writing 5%, Grammar 5%
- Oral assessment 1 (20%)
- Written assessment 2 (25%)
- Oral assessment 2 (20%)
- Attendance, participation (10%, not clear how it is calculated)

Assessments 1 are conducted in two consecutive lecture sessions. Same with assessments 2.

Absolute grading, where 90%+ = A range, 80%+ = B range, etc.

Here are my results:
* Grades were deleted after the end of the Spring term, so these are based on memory
Listening, reading, and grammar 1 (20/20)
Writing 1 (22/28)
Speaking/oral 1 (24/28)
Listening, reading, and grammar 2 (19/20)
Writing 2 (24/28)
Speaking/oral 2 (26/28)
LETTER GRADE == A
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload. Class discussions, two light homework (write a 150-word piece in full Hanzi with minimal pinyin), and revision for tests.

Definitely manageable! And classes are engaging too.

reviews.author: gyy
reviews.comment_content: You will cover 6 topics in total each about our daily life such as studying, finding jobs, and family values. It is not too difficult to understand, since Laoshi explains it so well. The words we learn from the class is also useful since it is mostly words that you can used in normal conversation
reviews.comment_teaching: Laoshi is very kind, and she is very good at teaching. She gives each of us the opportunity to speak and try to make the whole class do discussion
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not based on a curve, and it is subjective so it will be based solely on your language skill and you will not have to worry about how others are performing.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's a little homework that you have to complete like writing sentences and reading and answering some questions but you can get it done within a few days since it is not that much

There are two essays that you have to write for homework, and it may take quite some time to finish.

There is both midterm and final and each consist of 3 part: oral, writing and (reading and listening). The exam is conducted during class time, however, I feel like there's too much exam, since each part took up the whole class time, although for the oral you just have to speak for 5 minutes.

reviews.author: hungry
reviews.comment_content: Some topics will be more relevant than others, it is all based on the LANG1124 textbook and powerpoints. Some topics are: career and future plans, schooling, your impression of China.
reviews.comment_teaching: She's quite friendly, you can ask her questions and she'll try her best to answer (in English if necessary). Participation is encouraged, she often asks the class questions related to the content.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, it is based on attendance, as well as the assignments and exams you have submitted. The oral examination weighs a significant amount, but since it is subjective, you never really know how well you did until you get your grades back.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is manageable, but the real challenge comes from remembering the vocabulary and knowing how to use them correctly. Compared to other courses, this course has a light workload.

reviews.author: candid
reviews.title: LANG1124
reviews.comment_content:
First 7 lessons were fully covered from the LANG1124 textbook and only the grammar of the 8th lesson was covered.

Lesson 1 : 假期回顾
Lesson 2 : 中国印象
Lesson 3 : 我爱汉语
Lesson 4 : 年轻的一代
-------- Midterms --------
Lesson 5 : 大学生的前途
Lesson 6 : 我的重大决定
Lesson 7 : 机遇和条件
Lesson 8 : 我的理想
-------- Finals --------

Midterms and Finals both have the same format
Oral (20%)
Listening (10%)
Grammar (5%)
Reading (5%)
Writing (5%)

Assignment (5%)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Depends on how interested you are in Chinese. She uses the textbook for the overall content and makes separate PPTs for the grammar. She tries to encourage participation by writing questions on the board for students to answer.
How fun the course will be almost solely depends on how engaged you are in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely lenient; an easy A course.
The professor takes into account each students' Chinese abilities and seems to grade accordingly.
As long as you are familiar with the vocabulary and grammar, it's easy to get a perfect score on the listening, grammar, and reading portions of the midterm and final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Usually a week is spent on each lesson, sometimes up to a week and a half to 2 weeks.
There are 5 written assignments that should be at least 200 characters per assignment, but each won't take longer than half an hour.
The most workload heavy part of LANG1124 is the speaking portions of the midterm and final exams as you are only allowed to prepare a PPT for a 5 minute presentation as your presentation aid. Notecards and scripts are not allowed, meaning you have to have memorized your speech.

reviews.author: Keju
reviews.comment_content: Quite a lot of content. Around 50 new vocabulary words and ~3-5 words to use in a sentence (and, not only..but also, etc) per chapter, which is a lot, especially if you don't use Mandarin a lot. I don't know why I was put in this class when I asked for LANG 1122. On the bright side, it made me learn a lot of new vocabularies. There are also some words they expect you to already know, I guess those are the ones in 1120-1123, so you might have some extra words to learn. Other words that are not explicitly listed in the vocabulary lists will also be helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is really nice and will always try to help you. She tries to explain things nicely and clearly, although sometimes she may have trouble translating. Overall really friendly and helpful. Classes are interactive.
reviews.comment_grading: Attendance is required, just like any other LANG class. The grading should be absolute since, again, it's a LANG class. It's hard to get 'good grades'. I thought I would be in A range but ended up getting B+.
reviews.comment_workload: About 4-5 composition (120+ words) to write throughout the semester. One of the examination is an oral exam where you basically give a speech (with or without a powerpoint presentation, your choice) in front of the whole class in Chinese. You will have 2 of these. Other than that, you'll have writing examinations, split into 2: writing (short essay) and reading comprehension, short answer, listening, create a sentence. Workload is pretty light in my opinion. Those are your Mid-term Exam and Final Exam.

reviews.author: PimpDaddy
reviews.title: Vocabulary-heavy mixed background class
reviews.comment_content: The content is all about PSK Level 4. Basic words related to finding a job, travelling, and life in general. This class is a dumping ground for unusual Chinese background people. If you have taken only 1120 but self-studied more Chinese, you could take this class directly but your listening/speaking skills might be weak. If you have lived in China for a long time but have no formal qualifications and you can't really read or write Chinese, then you could take this class. If you were not good enough for 1113, then you could be placed in this class but you cannot move any lower. What can you teach students with such different backgrounds? You mainly teach them vocabulary so they can become on the same level afterwards. You should expect to learn hundreds of words (all of Level 4) after you have finished this class. This includes speaking, listening, and reading but not hand-writing. You must know the Pinyin, however.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Xu was perfectly acceptable; neither outstanding nor terrible. She is an earnest teacher who is trying to teach her students the basics of survival Chinese. She's possibly the most qualified/senior Chinese instructor available because her main priority is the most advanced Chinese class for native speakers. This class, by comparison, is for babies so she teaches everything in a very basic way.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading system was not at all transparent. You must complete ~4 hand-written essays for homework, 2 oral presentations in Chinese, and there are 2 comprehensive examinations. The exams take 2 classes because they cover listening, reading, and writing. The speaking portion is what the presentations are for, so make sure you get a native speaker to check your speech and practice it a lot. You can use any combination of Mandarin, Cantonese, and Pinyin in the written exams so long as your meaning can be understood.
Because you are graded on an absolute scale, you are not competing with your classmates so it is quite reasonable. Do these things and your grade will be great. You will be punished for any absence (for any reason!) so try to attend class
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was extremely light for me. The main point of this class is to teach you vocabulary: you will be expected to know all of PSK Level 4 at the end of this class and you are expected to have already learned Levels 1-3. Your main task is to memorise all the vocabulary words. You do not, however, need to memorise how to write these new words. Make sure you can recognise, pronounce, and read all of these words and you will be fine. The essays and presentations are designed to be straightforward. This was possibly the lowest workload class I have ever taken in HKUST.

reviews.author: 黄
reviews.comment_content:
The material consists of 4 chapters for every assessment (but 9 chapters in total). Basically every chapter has its own topic and reading material (pin yin included). The topics would vary from "holiday" to "work space". Every chapter has its own "new vocabulary" list which is around 50++ new words. Sometimes the instructor will give you listening practices, grammar learning, and also "making sentence" practice.

In my opinion, the material is a little bit too much for non-mandarin speaker. In the other hand, I do learn a lot of new vocabulary (but it should vary for different people).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Xu, Xiufen is a very friendly, encouraging, and caring teacher. She was aware that the students proficiency in mandarin are different, so she would  estimate your proficiency level and slow down if you need to.

She said that since the class was small (only around 10 people in the class this term), she were willing to explain more in class for the people who had not understand (just remember to ask, if you stay quiet, she could assume that all is okay).
reviews.comment_grading:
Basically there are 2 assessments, with grammar, listening, writing, and speaking tests for each assessment.

Got B+ for final grading.

For grammar test there would be fill in the blank, arranging words, and reading comprehension test.

For listening test there would be MCQs and T/F questions.

For speaking she would give you the topic and prompts.

You may use pin yin for the writing exam.

*People say it is absolute grading
reviews.comment_workload: There would be 4-5 essays you would need to write (150-200 words). The real work load is trying to understand the course itself (especially for the assessments). There are no other assignments other than these essays.

reviews.author: wkwkwkkwkw
reviews.title: Very nice lao shi
reviews.comment_content:
UNIT ONE:
第一课: 假期回顾
第二课: 中国印象
第三课: 我爱汉语

UNIT TWO:
第四课: 年轻的一代
第五课: 大学生的前途
第六课: 我的重大决定

UNIT THREE:
第七课: 机遇和挑战
第八课: 我的理想

So far, I would say the content is decent. Not that interesting but not boring either. The purpose of this course is to basically train you for HSK 4. So for those who have learned Chinese in high school this course should be pretty okay.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr/Lao Shi Xiufen is not only a great instructor but is also very kind and patient. It's obvious that she genuinely cares about her students' progress, so if you are confused about the course content feel free to contact her, she will be more than happy to answer your questions.

She always makes sure that every student in class is able to keep up with her lessons which is great.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Oral Examination One (talk about your daily activities on the internet and the impact it had on you)
25% Midterm (Listening 10%, Grammar 5%, Reading 5%, Writing 5%)
20% Oral Examination Two (talk about your future plans)
25% Final Exam (Listening 10%, Grammar 5%, Reading 5%, Writing 5%)
10% Assignments, attendance and participation (IF I'm not mistaken. She didn't really disclose what gets graded in this 10%)

Be very careful in the listening section because no texts are provided in the options, which means you'll have to listen very closely to the recording.

From what I've heard, this course adopts the absolute grading scheme, which is great as there are lots of smurfs here lmao.

My letter grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. Just do assignments and memorise pin yin (quite tedious and time consuming ngl).
